A single Ogham stone, binding the winds of magic and corrupting the lands for the benefit of the rest of the world.
A small circle of Ogham stones, more effective together than each of them would be on its own.
A medium-sized circle of Ogham stones, attracting magic from around the world and binding it to the earth of Albion, thus tainting fauna and flora.
A big circle of Ogham stones. Air and soil are saturated with magic, ready to be utilized by those with the required knowledge and ability.
Danu, the Earthmother, is the most worshipped goddess of the people of Albion. Shrines in her honor can be found in many villages around the island.
Bigger cities sometimes have temples at sacred sites where the power of the Earthmother is supposed to be strongest.
It is said that Danu herself blessed these places and that sometimes she can be witnessed to visit them in disguise.
A small, crudely scrambled together hut which serves as a basis of operation for local hunters.
A sturdy wooden building where hunters prepare for their next expedition into the dangerous wilds of Albion.
A grand hall displaying trophies of impressive hunts of the past. The best hunters meet here to practice their craft.
A place for the leaders of the tribe to gather and solve internal problems, sometimes through ritual combat.
The Chieftains and Elders meet to discuss questions of law. Young nobles and promising warriors are also trained in matters of tribal law.
The leaders of the most important local tribes meet here with their most capable advisors to avoid internal warfare - mostly without bloodshed.
A blacksmith is necessary to build the more advanced weapons used by the warriors of Albion.
Smithing is not as developed in Albion as it is in most of the more sophisticated civilizations, however, their craftsmen are still talented and can produce items of great worth and beauty.
An open field where warriors hone their skills in training duels.
A primitive but sturdy wooden structure in the heart of Albion settlements, where experienced warriors teach others in their craft.
The hall of an important chieftain where the elite of Albion's warriors gathers.
Barely more than a grassy field where the horses of the tribe are kept.
A wooden fence keeps the horses inside and the smaller predatory beasts of the wild out.
A wooden building shielding the cavalry from the harsh weather of the island.
Wooden fences barely slow down attackers, but they can buy the defenders some valuable moments to arm themselves.
Barricades made from wood and scrap metal to deter enemies from quick raids or infiltration.
A wooden palisade that will slow approaching enemy armies and give the defenders a small advantage in the fight.
This big building was built in honor of the heroes of past and present. Being allowed to feast and train within its walls is regarded as one of the highest honors.
Watchtowers have been erected to guard against threats for this exclave.
Warriors constantly patrol the perimeters in search of hostile activities.
The tactical value of this spot justified bringing experienced warriors and mighty monsters to prevent it from falling into enemy hands.

The elevated ground near an Albion settlement sometimes attracts members of the elusive Highlander tribes or Feral Gryphons which will defend their territory against the more dangerous chaos monsters of the islands.
Settlements with stony hills nearby are much better suited for chariot races and produce more charioteers than settlements with only swampy areas around.

The Maiden's Halls serve as a meeting point for women who want to pick up the art of war. Experienced Sword Maidens and Huntresses teach their craft here to young women eager to walk the way of the warrior.
Those women who serve the Oracle as guards and scouts are the most experienced female warriors of each tribe.
